articles.headline: U.S. Prevails in Trade Dispute With China
articles.snippet: A World Trade Organization panel largely upheld tariffs imposed on Chinese-made steel pipes, tires and other products during the Bush administration.
articles.abstract: A World Trade Organization panel largely upheld tariffs imposed on Chinese-made steel pipes, tires and other products during the Bush administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States claimed victory Friday in a trade dispute with China, after a World Trade Organization panel largely upheld tariffs that were imposed on an array of Chinese-made steel pipes, tires and other products during the Bush administration.

articles.headline: Underwriting a Child’s Business Poses Pitfalls for Parents
articles.snippet: Parents can help their children, but when lending them money, Mom and Dad should think like professionals.
articles.abstract: Parents can help their children, but when lending them money, Mom and Dad should think like professionals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Nathan Deal and his wife invested $2 million to help their daughter and son-in-law open an outdoor sporting goods store. They eventually doubled down by guaranteeing bank debt worth $2 million more. The business failed in 2009, the children filed for bankruptcy and their elders are now scrambling to avoid the same fate.

articles.headline: The Iraq Archive: The Strands of a War
articles.snippet: A huge trove of secret field reports from the battlegrounds of Iraq sheds new light on the war, including such fraught subjects as civilian deaths, detainee abuse and the involvement of Iran.
articles.abstract: A huge trove of secret field reports from the battlegrounds of Iraq sheds new light on the war, including such fraught subjects as civilian deaths, detainee abuse and the involvement of Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: A huge trove of secret field reports from the battlegrounds of Iraq sheds new light on the war, including such fraught subjects as civilian deaths, detainee abuse and the involvement of Iran.

articles.headline: A Grim Portrait of Civilian Deaths in Iraq
articles.snippet: The reports show that most civilians were killed by other Iraqis, but they also reveal many instances in which American soldiers killed civilians.
articles.abstract: The reports show that most civilians were killed by other Iraqis, but they also reveal many instances in which American soldiers killed civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The reports in the archive disclosed by WikiLeaks offer an incomplete, yet startlingly graphic portrait of one of the most contentious issues in the Iraq war — how many Iraqi civilians have been killed and by whom.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Leaked Reports Detail Iran’s Aid for Iraqi Militias
articles.snippet: The American military reports disclosed by WikiLeaks say Iran trained Iraqi militias and gave them weapons like rockets and bombs.
articles.abstract: The American military reports disclosed by WikiLeaks say Iran trained Iraqi militias and gave them weapons like rockets and bombs.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 22, 2006, American military officials in Baghdad issued a secret warning: The Shiite militia commander who had orchestrated the kidnapping of officials from Iraq’s Ministry of Higher Education was now hatching plans to take American soldiers hostage.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Democrats Back Third Parties to Siphon Votes
articles.snippet: Behind the scenes in tight races, Democrats are working to help candidates who hold the promise of taking Republican votes.
articles.abstract: Behind the scenes in tight races, Democrats are working to help candidates who hold the promise of taking Republican votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla.  Seeking any advantage in their effort to retain control of Congress, Democrats are working behind the scenes in a number of tight races to bolster long-shot third-party candidates who have platforms at odds with the Democratic agenda but hold the promise of siphoning Republican votes.

articles.headline: Neiman Marcus to Open New Bargain Outlets
articles.snippet: Neiman’s Last Call Studio stores will carry items bought directly from vendors that will be less expensive those at its existing Last Call outlet stores.
articles.abstract: Neiman’s Last Call Studio stores will carry items bought directly from vendors that will be less expensive those at its existing Last Call outlet stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Neiman Marcus may be known as a place for Texas-size yearnings and price tags, but in a sign of the economic times for luxury retailers, the company is being drawn to a less haughty shopper.

articles.headline: Tribune Chief Accepts Advice and Backs Out
articles.snippet: Sam Zell personally urged the controversial chief executive to step down after he became a dark sideshow.
articles.abstract: Sam Zell personally urged the controversial chief executive to step down after he became a dark sideshow.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tribune Company’s board resolved on Friday what had been its preoccupation for most of the week: sealing the fate of Randy Michaels, the controversial chief executive whose boorish behavior and cronyism became a dark sideshow to his bankrupt company’s financial struggles.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Big Problem for Banks: Due Process
articles.snippet: Why Bank of America shouldn’t count on putting its foreclosure problems behind it so quickly.
articles.abstract: Why Bank of America shouldn’t count on putting its foreclosure problems behind it so quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Bank of America, the nation’s largest consumer bank, reported its third-quarter earnings. It was a very good quarter; putting aside an accounting charge  a very large, $10.4 billion accounting charge, admittedly  the bank reported $3.1 billion in profits. It was the third consecutive quarter that Bank of America had earned more than $3 billion.

articles.headline: Marketers Can Glean Private Data on Facebook
articles.snippet: Two recent academic papers show that in certain circumstances, advertisers on Facebook may be able to learn sensitive profile information, like a person’s sexual orientation or religion.
articles.abstract: Two recent academic papers show that in certain circumstances, advertisers on Facebook may be able to learn sensitive profile information, like a person’s sexual orientation or religion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Online advertising offers marketers the chance to aim ads at very specific groups of people  say, golf players in Illinois who make more than $150,000 a year and vacation in Hawaii.

articles.headline: Plunging Rates for Refinancing Aid the Thrifty
articles.snippet: The frugal are qualifying for refinanced mortgages at interest rates that in any other recent era would have been considered stealing.
articles.abstract: The frugal are qualifying for refinanced mortgages at interest rates that in any other recent era would have been considered stealing.
articles.lead_paragraph: For those sober souls who were thrifty long before it became fashionable, the last few years have been intensely aggravating.

articles.headline: Use of Contractors Added to War’s Chaos in Iraq
articles.snippet: A trove of documents describes episodes in which private contractors killed civilians and were themselves killed.
articles.abstract: A trove of documents describes episodes in which private contractors killed civilians and were themselves killed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first shots sailed past Iraqi police officers at a checkpoint. They took off in three squad cars, their lights flashing.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: WikiLeaks Founder on the Run, Trailed by Notoriety
articles.snippet: Julian Assange is used to being denounced, but now some of his own comrades are abandoning him for what they see as erratic and imperious behavior.
articles.abstract: Julian Assange is used to being denounced, but now some of his own comrades are abandoning him for what they see as erratic and imperious behavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Julian Assange moves like a hunted man. In a noisy Ethiopian restaurant in London’s rundown Paddington district, he pitches his voice barely above a whisper to foil the Western intelligence agencies he fears.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: On Stump, Obama Takes Sharper Tone
articles.snippet: President Obama, sounding more subdued than he did in his own campaign in 2008, spent four days on the road trying to help fellow Democrats.
articles.abstract: President Obama, sounding more subdued than he did in his own campaign in 2008, spent four days on the road trying to help fellow Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  President Obama walked the campaign stage with the same familiar command, to the same music as 2008, same piercing cheers, same “We love you” cries from the crowd and “I love you backs” from the president and the occasional “Yes we can” chant.

articles.headline: Iran Is Said to Give Top Karzai Aide Cash by the Bagful
articles.snippet: A secret stream of Iranian cash intended to promote Iran’s interests in the Afghan presidential palace is seen as an effort to divide the U.S. and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: A secret stream of Iranian cash intended to promote Iran’s interests in the Afghan presidential palace is seen as an effort to divide the U.S. and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  One evening last August, as President Hamid Karzai wrapped up an official visit to Iran, his personal plane sat on the airport tarmac, waiting for a late-running passenger: Iran’s ambassador to Afghanistan.

articles.headline: One Mess That Can’t Be Papered Over
articles.snippet: It is possible, but difficult, to clean up the paperwork mess affecting mortgages. But for mortgage-backed securities, the complications are far trickier.
articles.abstract: It is possible, but difficult, to clean up the paperwork mess affecting mortgages. But for mortgage-backed securities, the complications are far trickier.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWYERS representing delinquent homeowners have been shouting for years about documentation problems in residential mortgages. Now that their complaints have gained traction with investors, attorneys general and some state court officials, the question of consequences looms large.

articles.headline: With Kinect, Microsoft Aims for a Game Changer
articles.snippet: The Kinect lets players control games with their bodies and speech. Will it be the hit product Microsoft wants?
articles.abstract: The Kinect lets players control games with their bodies and speech. Will it be the hit product Microsoft wants?
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Is Poised to Seize House, if Not Senate
articles.snippet: Republicans have placed enough seats into play that Washington is on the brink of a substantial shift in the balance of power.
articles.abstract: Republicans have placed enough seats into play that Washington is on the brink of a substantial shift in the balance of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A costly and polarizing Congressional campaign heads into its closing week with Republicans in a strong position to win the House but with Democrats maintaining a narrow edge in the battle for the Senate, according to a race-by-race review and lawmakers and strategists on both sides.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Should BP’s Money Go Where the Oil Didn’t?
articles.snippet: Oil from the BP spill never came close to most of Florida’s beaches, but tourists seemed to be scared off anyway. Businesses and want restitution for lost revenue.
articles.abstract: Oil from the BP spill never came close to most of Florida’s beaches, but tourists seemed to be scared off anyway. Businesses and want restitution for lost revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETE BEACH, Fla.

articles.headline: In Haiti, Capital Braces for a Cholera Outbreak
articles.snippet: Worry is growing that a cholera epidemic that began last week in the northwest will soon strike the Port-au-Prince area.
articles.abstract: Worry is growing that a cholera epidemic that began last week in the northwest will soon strike the Port-au-Prince area.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  In the raggedy Sinai tent camp, a 7-year-old with a distended belly and missing front teeth struggled to dump a bucket filled with watery diarrhea in a putrid outhouse.

articles.headline: Drug Testing Poses Quandary for Employers
articles.snippet: Workplace testing is drawing complaints from employees who say they should not be fired for taking legal drugs.
articles.abstract: Workplace testing is drawing complaints from employees who say they should not be fired for taking legal drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCEBURG, Tenn.  The news, delivered in a phone call, left Sue Bates aghast: she was losing her job of 22 years after testing positive for a legally prescribed drug.
articles.byline: By Katie Zezima and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: Against Odds, Web Site Finds Niche
articles.snippet: The Awl confronts the tyranny of small numbers in an age when Web behemoths, like Gawker Media and The Huffington Post, get most of the attention.
articles.abstract: The Awl confronts the tyranny of small numbers in an age when Web behemoths, like Gawker Media and The Huffington Post, get most of the attention.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something odd showed up last week in the mailbox of Choire Sicha, a veteran blogger who lost his job and started a Web site with a few pals two years ago: a paycheck.

articles.headline: App Makers Take Interest in Android
articles.snippet: As Android phones gain market share, many app makers are rethinking their exclusive focus on iPhones.
articles.abstract: As Android phones gain market share, many app makers are rethinking their exclusive focus on iPhones.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was cold beer, hot pizza and shop talk at a recent informal gathering of Android programmers in downtown Manhattan. Inevitably the chatter turned to money.

articles.headline: TV Watchdog Group Is on the Defensive
articles.snippet: The Parents Television Council has been hurt by court challenges to the F.C.C. and low finances.
articles.abstract: The Parents Television Council has been hurt by court challenges to the F.C.C. and low finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — These are difficult days for the decency police.

articles.headline: MTV Is Looking Beyond ‘Jersey Shore’ to Build a Wider Audience
articles.snippet: MTV, which is enjoying a renaissance thanks to shows like “Jersey Shore,” hopes to build on that success by rapidly diversifying its slate of programs.
articles.abstract: MTV, which is enjoying a renaissance thanks to shows like “Jersey Shore,” hopes to build on that success by rapidly diversifying its slate of programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The second-season finale of “Jersey Shore” last week was one of the highest-rated hours all year on MTV. There was, perhaps, no better time to promote another boozy, in-your-face unscripted show.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Gains Sway, but Its Authority Is Uncertain
articles.snippet: Whether the International Monetary Fund is up to the task of policing its members and exerting influence on the most powerful ones remains far from clear.
articles.abstract: Whether the International Monetary Fund is up to the task of policing its members and exerting influence on the most powerful ones remains far from clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Can the International Monetary Fund achieve what seems like a mission impossible: bridge the increasingly tense currency and trade disputes that threaten to set back the uneven global recovery?

articles.headline: Obama’s Playbook After Nov. 2
articles.snippet: After two years of operating at loggerheads with Republicans, the president and his aides are planning a post-election agenda for a different political climate.
articles.abstract: After two years of operating at loggerheads with Republicans, the president and his aides are planning a post-election agenda for a different political climate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It took President Obama 18 months to invite the Senate Republican leader, Mitch McConnell, to the White House for a one-on-one chat. Their Aug. 4 session in the Oval Office  30 minutes of private time, interrupted only when the president’s daughter Malia called from summer camp to wish her father a happy 49th birthday  was remarkable, not for what was said, but for what it took to make it happen.

articles.headline: Pro-Republican Groups Prepare Big Push at End of Races
articles.snippet: Anonymously financed groups are starting a coordinated final push to deliver control of Congress to Republicans.
articles.abstract: Anonymously financed groups are starting a coordinated final push to deliver control of Congress to Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: OVIEDO, Fla. — The anonymously financed conservative groups that have played such a crucial role this campaign year are starting a carefully coordinated final push to deliver control of Congress to Republicans, shifting money among some 80 House races they are monitoring day by day.

articles.headline: Short Sales Resisted as Foreclosures Are Revived
articles.snippet: Homeowners could face pressure from lenders’ reluctance to allow sales for less than what remains on the mortgage.
articles.abstract: Homeowners could face pressure from lenders’ reluctance to allow sales for less than what remains on the mortgage.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Bank of America and GMAC are firing up their formidable foreclosure machines again today, after a brief pause.

articles.headline: Foreclosures Had Errors, Bank Finds
articles.snippet: As Bank of America begins to restart foreclosure proceedings, the bank said that it had discovered errors, including incorrect data and misspelled names, in the paperwork it had reviewed.
articles.abstract: As Bank of America begins to restart foreclosure proceedings, the bank said that it had discovered errors, including incorrect data and misspelled names, in the paperwork it had reviewed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Bank of America begins to restart foreclosure proceedings in 23 states on Monday, the bank confirmed that it had discovered errors, including incorrect data and misspelled names, in the paperwork it has reviewed.

articles.headline: Afghan Leader Admits His Office Gets Cash from Iran
articles.snippet: President Hamid Karzai said that he uses an off-the-books fund to pay expenses incurred in the course of doing his job.
articles.abstract: President Hamid Karzai said that he uses an off-the-books fund to pay expenses incurred in the course of doing his job.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai acknowledged on Monday that he regularly receives bags of cash from the Iranian government in payments amounting to millions of dollars, as evidence mounted of a worsening rift between his government and its American and NATO supporters.
articles.byline: By Dexter Filkins and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Mortgage Modifications Slow in September
articles.snippet: A report showed that the number of delinquent homeowners who had tried and failed to get a new loan significantly exceeded the number who had succeeded.
articles.abstract: A report showed that the number of delinquent homeowners who had tried and failed to get a new loan significantly exceeded the number who had succeeded.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as banks, borrowers and regulators battle over how much faulty documentation by lenders should impede foreclosures, fresh evidence came Monday that the housing market remained very wobbly.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Binyamin Appelbaum
